title: 106_hr4683
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Patent Act of 2000". The Congress recognizes the strength and quality of US patents, defining them as private property rights. The US leads in intellectual property, with patents being crucial for societal and economic growth, job creation, and raising living standards. Patents drive innovation, increase income, and facilitate trade for the country. The successful 207-year-old Federal agency responsible for issuing patents can provide expertise and support for other countries. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director of the Patent and Trademark Office" refers to the Under Secretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property and the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office. The term "Patent and Trademark Office" refers to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. The term "GSP country" refers to a beneficiary developing country under title V of the Trade Act of 1974. SEC. 4. SOVEREIGN DUTIES OF THE PATENT AND TRADEMARK OFFICE. The Director of the Patent and Trademark Office is responsible for establishing a US/GSP International Country Notification Office for issuing patents valid in both the United States and GSP countries. They must ensure that patents meet standards applicable to US law and oversee examination duties for granting patents valid in the US. The Director of the Patent and Trademark Office is responsible for establishing a trust fund for each GSP country with which the United States has an agreement under subsection (b) to assist in enhancing the patent system in that country. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, will negotiate agreements with GSP countries desiring patents to be issued under this Act. The Director of the Patent and Trademark Office establishes a trust fund for GSP countries to enhance their patent systems through technical assistance and education programs. 15% of patent fees and a special handling fee are deposited into the fund for each patent application or patent issued valid in both the United States and the respective country. The United States provides computer search facilities with the patent database to each GSP country. The Secretary of Commerce and the Director of the Patent and Trademark Office determine a fee for using patent search facilities in GSP countries. The Secretary of State provides computer search facilities at the US embassy in each GSP country. The Small Business Administration will provide information to GSP countries on creating small businesses based on patents. The Agency for International Development will implement a program to help GSP countries develop patent systems for economic growth.
